importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Paris Climate Agreement was signed in 2015, setting a global target to limit warming to 2°C, which directly influences the projected future number of superhot days.
The study references warming trajectories from 1991 to 2020 as baseline, indicating that the climate baseline for comparison is anchored in this period.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects future increases in superhot days up to 2100, highlighting long-term climate risks and the urgency of current mitigation efforts.
The article is published in 2025, placing the analysis within the context of near-term climate policy and public awareness.

keyTakeAways: The world is projected to see 57 additional superhot days per year by 2100 due to climate change, even under current emissions commitments.
This is half the number predicted under a worst-case scenario of 4°C warming, which would have added 114 superhot days annually.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days per year.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa are expected to face the largest increases in dangerous heat days — up to 149 extra days annually.
These 10 countries collectively produce just 1% of global carbon emissions, yet face the greatest heat exposure.
In contrast, top carbon polluters like the U.S., China, and India — responsible for 42% of global CO2 — face only 23–30 extra superhot days.
The growing disparity in heat exposure based on emissions levels highlights a significant global injustice and could contribute to geopolitical tensions.
Experts warn that tens of thousands or even millions of people will be affected by increased heat events annually, with thousands already dying in heatwaves each year.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It conducted the study that quantifies the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific credibility to the findings.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming to well below 2°C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the study’s analysis, as it changed the trajectory of global warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, reducing the number of superhot days.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central estimates that even under current climate commitments, the planet will face 57 additional superhot days per year by 2100 — nearly two months of dangerous heat — due to climate change. This represents a significant improvement from the worst-case scenario of 114 extra days under 4°C warming, but still poses severe risks. The report highlights a stark global inequity: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa — which produce just 1% of global emissions — will face dramatic spikes in heat exposure, while major emitters like the U.S., China, and India face only a small fraction of the added heat. Experts warn that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected, with thousands already dying in heatwaves each year. The findings underscore both the urgency of climate action and the deep injustice in how climate change impacts are distributed across nations.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
